intro: Atriplex hortensis var. obtusifolia, commonly known as lamb's-quarters, is a flowering plant in the family Amaranthaceae. It is characterized by its succulent, lobed leaves that are often covered in a fine layer of white powder, known as farina. The plant produces small, greenish flowers that are clustered in dense spikes, typically appearing in late summer. It is native to Europe, Asia, and North Africa but has been naturalized in many parts of the world. This species is often found in disturbed soils and can thrive in a variety of environmental conditions.
